bestBHT.bht: By handing down traditions, one must be cautious as it can lead to the invalidation of God's word. Christ perceives the Jewish persecutors and bigots, past and present, as driven by a shared spirit. They wrongly ascribe the actions of one group to another, making void the word of God. This act of setting aside traditions goes beyond mere dismissal - it carries the weight of invalidation. It is crucial to prioritize God's commandments over human traditions or vows, even if it means recognizing and repenting from the follies of the past.

Henry Alford: 13.] A repetition from ver. 8;—common in Mark.
Marvin Vincent: Ye handed down. Note the past tense, identifying them for the moment with their forefathers.
Christ views the Jewish persecutors and bigots, ancient and modern, as a whole, actuated by one spirit.
Ascribes to one section what was done by another.
Philip Schaff: Mark 7:13. The last clause of Mark 7:8 was probably taken from this verse.
Archibald T. Robertson: Making void the word of God by your tradition.
Invalidating, a stronger word than to set aside.
John Gill: That a vow made rashly, and in a passion, or if ever so deliberately entered into, should be more binding upon a man than the law of God...
...he should transgress a divine command; and that though he might see his folly, and repent of his sin in making such a wicked vow, he could not go back from it...
...he ought rather to attend, than to the words of the law, that he should keep and fulfil his vow, whatever command was neglected or broken by it.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse speaks of the act of handing down traditions and how it can make void the word of God. This concept is reiterated in the repetition from verse 8, as Christ views the Jewish persecutors and bigots, both ancient and modern, as a collective group, unified by their spirit. The act of setting aside traditions does not simply dismiss or disregard them, but rather carries a weight that invalidates the word of God. This understanding sheds light on the gravity of the situation, emphasizing the importance of remaining steadfast to the truth of God's commandments rather than being bound by human traditions and vows which may lead to transgressions.

The act of handing down traditions can have detrimental consequences, as it can make void the word of God. Christ sees the Jewish persecutors and bigots, ancient and modern, as a collective group driven by a shared spirit. Setting aside traditions is not a mere dismissal, but a serious invalidation of God's word. This highlights the weightiness of the situation, urging us to prioritize the truth of God's commandments over human traditions or vows, which can lead to transgressions.

By handing down traditions, one must be cautious as it can lead to the invalidation of God's word. Christ perceives the Jewish persecutors and bigots, past and present, as driven by a shared spirit. They wrongly ascribe the actions of one group to another, making void the word of God. This act of setting aside traditions goes beyond mere dismissal - it carries the weight of invalidation. It is crucial to prioritize God's commandments over human traditions or vows, even if it means recognizing and repenting from the follies of the past.

Handing down traditions can have grave consequences, making void the word of God. Jesus sees Jewish persecutors and bigots, both ancient and modern, as united by a shared spirit. They attribute the actions of one group to another, setting aside the word of God. This act of invalidation is stronger than mere dismissal. It is vital to prioritize God's commandments over human traditions or vows, even if it means recognizing and repenting from past sins committed in ignorance.

The act of handing down traditions can make void the word of God. Jesus views Jewish persecutors and bigots, ancient and modern, as united by one spirit. They wrongly attribute the actions of one group to another, invalidating God's word. This act of setting aside traditions is stronger than mere dismissal. It is crucial to prioritize God's commandments over human traditions or vows, even if it means recognizing and repenting from past sins committed in ignorance.
